args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject represents a more specific subtype or subset of the object within a taxonomic or categorical hierarchy.
args.justification: The relation describes 'female butterflies' as a subset of 'butterflies' in a taxonomic sense, which is a standard subtype/subclass relationship; using a normalized predicate 'is_subtype_of' aligns with common hierarchy modeling.
This edge connects a specific category (female butterflies) to a broader category (butterflies) in a class hierarchy, fitting a taxonomic/ontological hierarchy relation class.
Subtype/supertype relations refine identity and categorization of entities rather than describing composition or causality, so they fall under a broad identity/classification dimension.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject physically surrounds or encases the object (or the entity in that state) during a specified stage or time interval.
args.justification: The description states that the chrysalis is the protective casing that encloses the caterpillar during the pupa stage; this is best modeled as a spatial enclosure qualified by a temporal stage, matching the predicate 'encloses_during'.
args.remark: The object node is the pupa stage rather than the organism itself; the description implies enclosing the organism during that stage, but the predicate still captures the intended stage-bounded enclosure.

args.justification: The relation captures that one biological structure (chrysalis) structurally contains/encloses another entity during a life stage, fitting a structural containment / enclosure class.
The primary semantics involve spatial enclosure (one structure surrounding another), with the temporal aspect handled via qualifiers rather than the broad relation group.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject exhibits the given physical or qualitative state at the initial time of a process or immediately after a specified event.
args.justification: The description explicitly states that butterfly wings are in a soft, wrinkled state right after emergence, which is a canonical example of an initial state property; the hint already matches this semantics.

This edge links a biological structure (wings) to a descriptive physical state it possesses at a certain time, which is best captured as a state/property relation rather than, e.g., composition or hierarchy.
The focus is on the physical state of an entity at a particular moment (initial condition), which is most naturally placed in a broad STATE group distinct from causality or composition.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a life cycle process or sequence comprises the given life stage as one of its constituent phases.
args.justification: Both relations connect the butterfly life cycle to specific life stages (larval/caterpillar and adult) as constituent phases; a single predicate 'includes_life_stage' cleanly normalizes these semantically identical stage-inclusion relations.
Both edges express that a life cycle process is composed of, or structured as, distinct stages; grouping them under a life-cycle stage composition class captures this shared semantics across stages.
These relations describe how a complex process (life cycle) is composed of its constituent stages, fitting naturally into a broad COMPOSITION dimension rather than pure temporality or causality.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a biological life stage or entity occurs on, or is situated on, the surface of another physical entity (e.g., eggs on plant leaves).
args.justification: All four relations describe the egg stage being spatially situated on a substrate (host plants, plant leaves, or the underside of leaves). Despite minor wording differences (located_on, occurs_on), they share the same spatial predicate meaning: the life stage occurs on the surface of a physical support. A single canonical predicate 'occurs_on_surface_of' captures this consistently.

Each relation links a butterfly life stage (egg stage) to its typical physical substrate/habitat (host plants, plant leaves, leaf undersides). This is best modeled as a class of relations connecting organism life stages to their environmental or substrate context.

The core semantics of these relations is spatial: the egg stage is physically located on or occurs on the surface of particular plants or leaves. Even when causal or functional qualifiers are mentioned (e.g., protection from predators), the relation itself is explicitly spatial.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject causally affects the duration or length of time associated with the object process or state.
args.justification: The description and qualifiers indicate a causal dependency where butterfly species affects how long metamorphosis lasts, best modeled as influencing the duration of the object process.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the existence, value, or magnitude of the subject property is causally dependent on the object entity or factor.
args.justification: Here the subject (adult butterfly lifespan) is explicitly described as depending on the butterfly species, so a directional dependency predicate from effect to cause is appropriate.

All three relations express that life-history traits (egg traits, metamorphosis duration, adult lifespan) are causally constrained by or dependent on butterfly species; grouping them under a shared class for specieslife-history dependencies is coherent.
Each relation encodes a causal or dependency relationship (lifespan, traits, and process duration varying depending on species), which fits the broad CAUSALITY group.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The caterpillar (larval) stage follows the egg stage as the second stage of the butterfly life cycle.

remarks: Complementary to the develops_into relation; included to make the temporal order explicit.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that one biological life-cycle stage temporally precedes and developmentally leads into another stage within the same organism's life cycle.
args.justification: All three relations describe a life-cycle stage that occurs before and develops into the next stage in the butterfly life cycle (egg  larva, larva  pupa, pupa  adult). The dominant semantics are temporal ordering within a life cycle plus developmental progression, so a unified predicate 'precedes_in_life_cycle' captures this consistently for all three edges.
args.remark: Though the descriptions mention 'develops into', the primary axis modeled here is ordered progression of life stages; more detailed developmental/causal semantics can be modeled with a separate predicate if needed.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that one biological life-cycle stage temporally follows and results from another stage within the same organism's life cycle.
args.justification: This relation is explicitly the inverse direction of the egg  larva precedence relation: the larval stage follows the egg stage. To keep predicates directionally clear and consistent with the text ('follows'), a separate but inverse predicate 'follows_in_life_cycle' is appropriate rather than overloading the 'precedes' predicate.
args.remark: This predicate is the conceptual inverse of 'precedes_in_life_cycle'; an ontology-level inverse relation axiom could connect the two.

args.justification: All four relations organize butterfly life stages in a temporal and developmental sequence (which stage comes before or after another). This is more specific than a generic temporal relation and naturally forms a class for ordering of life-cycle stages across organisms.
args.remark: This class can later be reused for similar stage-order relations in other organisms' life cycles (e.g., amphibians, insects).

args.justification: Each relation expresses temporal ordering between stages (precedes/follows) in a life cycle. While developmental progression is mentioned, the core semantic dimension is temporal sequence, fitting the TEMPORALITY group.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject organism or life stage obtains food by consuming the object, which serves as its trophic resource.
args.justification: All four relations describe trophic feeding interactions where an organism (adult butterflies, birds, reptiles, or other insects) uses the object as a food resource (nectar or a food-source role). Normalizing to a single predicate 'feeds_on' captures the biological feeding direction consistently.

Each relation expresses a predatorprey or consumerresource feeding link, which is a classic trophic interaction in an ecological food web. Grouping them under 'trophic_interaction_relation' reflects this shared ecological semantics.

Feeding and predatorprey relations are biological interactions between organisms (or organism life stages) and their food resources, fitting the broad INTERACTION dimension better than COMPOSITION or IDENTITY.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject substance or resource is generated, secreted, or produced by the object organism or structure.
args.justification: This relation states that nectar originates from flowers, i.e., nectar is produced by flowers. Using the passive-direction predicate 'is_produced_by' with subject=nectar and object=flowers makes the production/source semantics explicit and consistent.

The link describes the origin of a biological product (nectar) from a producing organismal structure (flowers). This fits a class for product/source or origin relations rather than trophic or hierarchical relations.
Flowers causally give rise to nectar as a secreted product; the relation encodes a generative source-effect link rather than simple association or composition, so it is best grouped under CAUSALITY.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that an organism or life stage repeatedly undergoes a specific biological process as part of its development or functioning.
args.justification: The subject is a caterpillar life stage and the object is the molting process it repeatedly undergoes during growth; this is best modeled as an organism (or life stage) undergoing a biological process, which is reusable beyond this specific example.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a developmental life cycle process is the characteristic life cycle of a given organism or taxon.
args.justification: The subject is the butterfly life cycle (a developmental process) and the object is butterflies (the organism group that undergoes this process); the most precise predicate is that this process is the life cycle of that organism.

Both relations link biological entities (organisms or life stages) with their developmental processes: one is an organism/life stage undergoing a process (molting), the other is an organism associated with its overall life cycle. These fit a common class covering organismdevelopmental-process relations.

At a broad level, both edges express non-causal, non-spatial associations between organisms (or their stages) and their characteristic biological/developmental processes, which fits an ASSOCIATION-type group better than COMPOSITION, CAUSALITY, or IDENTITY.

Both relations describe how a biological subject (caterpillars, food source role) causally affects higher-level ecological outcomes (plant population balance, biodiversity). Grouping them as ecological effect relations reflects this shared causal-outcome semantics.

Both relations express the ecological roles of butterflies/caterpillars: being an essential ecosystem component and serving as a food source (trophic role). These naturally belong to a common ecological-role class.
A food-provision link between plants and caterpillars is a classic biotic (trophic) interaction in ecology, best captured under an interaction-oriented group.
Both relations describe causal influences of the subject on an ecological state or outcome (maintenance of plant balance, biodiversity), which aligns with a causality-focused group.
Being an essential component of an ecosystem is a partwhole, system-composition relation, so a composition-oriented group is most appropriate.
Having a trophic role as a food source situates the organism within predatorprey interactions, which is naturally modeled under an interaction group.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a process or mechanism brings about a transformation of an entity or body, without specifying the resulting form.
args.justification: In this relation, the subject is the metamorphosis process and the object is the caterpillar body; the semantics are that the process transforms the entity, not that the entity becomes a specific resulting state. A process-to-entity transformation predicate is appropriate and distinct from result-oriented 'transforms_into' relations.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that an entity changes form or state into a specified resulting substance, structure, or configuration.
args.justification: Here the subject is 'organs' and the object is 'soupy substance'; the relation expresses a state change where the organs become the soupy substance during metamorphosis. This is a result-oriented transformation that should be distinguished from a generic process-transforms-entity predicate.

Both relations describe biological transformations during metamorphosis: one where a process transforms an organism's body, and another where organs change into a liquefied state. They belong to the same broader family of relations that capture changes in state or form, even though their canonical predicates differ in granularity.

Both edges capture transformation of entities (bodies, organs) into different forms or configurations, which fits the broad category of modifications or changes to existing entities rather than pure compositional or spatial relations.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that an organism in one life stage develops into and is replaced by the next defined life stage in its life cycle.
args.justification: This relation encodes a developmental progression from the caterpillar (larval stage) to the pupa stage as the next life stage. The predicate should reflect ordered life-stage transition rather than generic temporality.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that an organism or life stage physically emerges from a containing or enclosing biological structure.
args.justification: Both relations describe an adult butterfly (including the newly emerged variant) physically emerging from the chrysalis. They share the same directionality and semantics: an organismal stage coming out of an enclosing structure.

All three relations capture transitions in an organism's development: one between successive life stages (caterpillar to pupa) and two from an enclosing pupal structure to the adult life stage. Grouping them under a developmental-stage transition class is appropriate, even though one pair also involves an enclosing structure.

Each relation fundamentally encodes ordered changes over time in the butterfly's life cycleprogression to the next life stage or emergence after metamorphosisso they best fit a temporal/sequence-oriented group.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject is a collection or set that includes the object as one of its members.

args.justification: All four relations describe successive biological life stages of a butterfly where one stage changes into the next (egg to larva, larva to pupa, pupa to adult). They share the same directed developmental-transition semantics, so a single canonical predicate 'develops_into' is appropriate.

Each relation connects two consecutive life stages within the same organism's life cycle (egglarva, larvapupa, pupaadult). This is a specific family of relations about transitions between ordered life-cycle stages, so a dedicated class 'life_cycle_stage_transition_relation' is suitable.

The core semantics are about ordered progression over time in a life cycle (one stage precedes and then becomes the next). This is primarily temporal sequencing of states of the same entity, so the broad group 'TEMPORALITY' best fits.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a structure or region is filled internally with a particular fluid or substance as part of its physical state.
args.justification: The relation describes the wings being internally filled with wing fluid as a resulting state (soft, wrinkled wings are filled with wing fluid). This is best modeled as a containment/state predicate rather than a transport action.
The predicate expresses that a biological structure contains a fluid internally (wings contain wing fluid). This fits a class of relations about one entity being filled or occupied by a substance.
Being filled with a particular fluid describes the internal material composition/state of the wings rather than an action, so it belongs under a compositional group.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a fluid or substance is actively transported or pumped into a target structure or region.
args.justification: The relation explicitly states that wing fluid is pumped into the butterfly wings, emphasizing directional transport of a fluid into a structure, so a transport-oriented predicate is appropriate.
The predicate captures an active movement of biological fluid into a body structure, fitting a class of physiological transport or circulation relations rather than static composition.

The relation focuses on an active process (pumping fluid into wings), a dynamic interaction between fluid and structure, rather than merely describing composition, so INTERACTION is the best broad group.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that an organism uses another entity as a site or substrate for laying eggs (oviposition).

The relation expresses use of host plants as a biological resource (oviposition substrate) by female butterflies, fitting a class of resource/functional usage relations between organisms and environmental resources.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject feature or structure makes the object function or capability possible.
args.justification: The relation describes fully developed butterfly wings making flight possible; a general predicate 'enables' captures this functional enablement between structure and capability.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject entity has the capability to perform or exhibit the object function.
args.justification: The adult butterfly life stage is described as being capable of flight; a capability relation from life stage to function is best modeled as 'has_capability_for'.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject structure is used to consume or ingest the object substance as food.
args.justification: The proboscis is functionally used to drink (consume) nectar; modeling this as 'used_to_consume' captures the tool-like use of a body part to ingest a food resource.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Links a reproductive agent (e.g., adult female organism) to the life stage whose occurrence it initiates (e.g., egg stage) through reproduction.

The core semantics is that the subject causally initiates the object life stage, not merely containing or being part of it, so a unified predicate 'initiates_life_stage' fits both instances.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Links an organism or life stage to a protective physical structure that it forms around or from its own body (e.g., a caterpillar forming a chrysalis).

args.canonical_rel_desc: Links a multi-stage biological process (e.g., a life cycle) to one of its constituent life stages (e.g., egg, larva, pupa, adult).

Grouping them under 'reproductive_stage_initiation_relation' captures that they are about reproduction-driven onset of a life stage, distinct from generic causation or structural formation.

The relation captures a life-stage driven structural transformation where the caterpillar creates a chrysalis around itself. This is best treated as a morphological transformation family of relations, not purely reproductive or compositional.
The subject is a multi-step process (butterfly life cycle) and the object is one of its stages (egg stage). This fits a class describing membership of stages within a broader biological process.

Female butterflies causally bring about the egg stage via reproductive action; the emphasis is on causing a new stage to begin, which is fundamentally causal rather than purely temporal sequencing or composition.

The caterpillar forms a chrysalis as a morphological change of its state and surrounding structure. This is best grouped under MODIFICATION (self-transformation) rather than generic CAUSALITY or COMPOSITION.

The butterfly life cycle is treated as a composite process made up of stages, one of which is the egg stage. The relation is about constitutive membership (part-whole) rather than direct causation or temporal ordering, so COMPOSITION is the most appropriate broad group.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a biological process or sequence of events produces or culminates in a particular outcome, state, or life stage.
args.justification: All three relations describe a process or journey (metamorphosis or the butterfly's life journey) that leads to a defined outcome (adult butterfly stage or a final state associated with it). They are straightforward causal outcome links where the subject process results in the object outcome.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a process or factor helps maintain or stabilize a particular ecological or system state.
args.justification: This relation states that pollination helps maintain the balance of plant populations. The semantics are that pollination is a contributing factor to the ongoing maintenance of an ecological state, not a single decisive outcome, so a "contributes_to_maintenance_of" predicate captures this nuance.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a substance, component, or intermediate state plays a contributing role in forming new tissues, structures, or entities.
args.justification: The relation explicitly describes the liquefied "soupy substance" as functionally contributing to the formation of new tissues and structures during metamorphosis. A predicate centered on contribution to formation accurately reflects this partial, process-role causality.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a process or factor makes reproduction of a given organism or group possible or facilitates it, without necessarily being solely sufficient.
args.justification: The instance describes pollination as enabling plants to reproduce, with qualifiers noting it is facilitating rather than strictly sufficient. A predicate that explicitly encodes enabling of reproduction for the object organisms matches the instance semantics.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a process or behavior supports or underpins the continuation or persistence of a life cycle, population, or system.
args.justification: The relation describes butterfly reproduction as supporting the continuation of the butterfly life cycle. This is a sustaining, underpinning causal role for an ongoing cycle rather than a single discrete outcome, so a "supports_continuation_of" predicate is appropriate.

All relations link biological processes, substances, or life-history events to their outcomes or system-level effects: maintaining ecological balance, enabling reproduction, supporting life-cycle continuation, contributing to tissue formation, and resulting in an adult stage or associated state. These are all instances of causal outcome/effect relations within biological and ecological contexts, so they fit a shared class capturing biological process outcomes and effects.

Each relation expresses a causal or enabling link: processes or substances leading to or supporting outcomes such as reproduction, tissue formation, life-cycle continuation, or adult stages. They are all inherently about causes and effects, so the broad group CAUSALITY is appropriate.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a biological process or sequence of events produces or culminates in a particular outcome, state, or life stage.
executed_decisions.justification: All three relations describe a process or journey (metamorphosis or the butterfly's life journey) that leads to a defined outcome (adult butterfly stage or a final state associated with it). They are straightforward causal outcome links where the subject process results in the object outcome.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a process or factor helps maintain or stabilize a particular ecological or system state.
executed_decisions.justification: This relation states that pollination helps maintain the balance of plant populations. The semantics are that pollination is a contributing factor to the ongoing maintenance of an ecological state, not a single decisive outcome, so a "contributes_to_maintenance_of" predicate captures this nuance.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a substance, component, or intermediate state plays a contributing role in forming new tissues, structures, or entities.
executed_decisions.justification: The relation explicitly describes the liquefied "soupy substance" as functionally contributing to the formation of new tissues and structures during metamorphosis. A predicate centered on contribution to formation accurately reflects this partial, process-role causality.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a process or factor makes reproduction of a given organism or group possible or facilitates it, without necessarily being solely sufficient.
executed_decisions.justification: The instance describes pollination as enabling plants to reproduce, with qualifiers noting it is facilitating rather than strictly sufficient. A predicate that explicitly encodes enabling of reproduction for the object organisms matches the instance semantics.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a process or behavior supports or underpins the continuation or persistence of a life cycle, population, or system.
executed_decisions.justification: The relation describes butterfly reproduction as supporting the continuation of the butterfly life cycle. This is a sustaining, underpinning causal role for an ongoing cycle rather than a single discrete outcome, so a "supports_continuation_of" predicate is appropriate.

All relations link biological processes, substances, or life-history events to their outcomes or system-level effects: maintaining ecological balance, enabling reproduction, supporting life-cycle continuation, contributing to tissue formation, and resulting in an adult stage or associated state. These are all instances of causal outcome/effect relations within biological and ecological contexts, so they fit a shared class capturing biological process outcomes and effects.

Each relation expresses a causal or enabling link: processes or substances leading to or supporting outcomes such as reproduction, tissue formation, life-cycle continuation, or adult stages. They are all inherently about causes and effects, so the broad group CAUSALITY is appropriate.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The caterpillar attaches its body to a leaf as part of forming the chrysalis.
cluster_relations.object_class_group: Biological Structures and Substances in Butterfly Metamorphosis

qualifiers.CausalHint: as it prepares for the next stage

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The caterpillar may attach itself to a stem as an alternative to a leaf when forming the chrysalis.
cluster_relations.object_class_group: Biological Structures and Substances in Butterfly Metamorphosis

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Adult butterflies visit flowers while feeding on nectar.
cluster_relations.object_class_label: Flowering plant reproductive structures and organisms

args.canonical_rel_desc: Subject organism physically secures or anchors itself to the surface of the object, typically as a substrate for a life-stage transition or resting.
args.justification: Both relations describe the same physical predicate: the caterpillar securing its body to a plant structure (leaf or stem) as a substrate during transition to the pupa/chrysalis stage. The object varies (leaf vs. stem) but the semantics of the edge are identical, so they should share a single canonical predicate 'attaches_to'.

These relations represent an organism attaching to a physical substrate (plant organ) as part of its life cycle. Grouping them under a class like 'substrate_attachment_relation' captures this specific family of physical interactions, more informative than a generic 'interaction' class.

The essence of these edges is a direct physical interaction between organism and substrate (caterpillarplant contact/anchoring), which fits best under a broad INTERACTION category rather than COMPOSITION or SPATIALITY alone.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Subject organism feeds at or on the object, which serves as the feeding site or resource location.
args.justification: The description specifies that adult butterflies visit flowers while feeding on nectar; the core semantics are that the butterfly uses the flower as a feeding site. A canonical predicate 'feeds_at' captures this trophic/feeding-location interaction more precisely and reuseably than the surface label 'visits'.

This edge encodes a trophic/feeding interaction between an animal and a plant resource (nectar from flowers). Classifying it as 'feeding_interaction_relation' correctly groups it with other predatorprey or consumerresource feeding edges, distinct from non-feeding physical attachments.
The butterflyflower feeding relationship is a direct biotic interaction (consumerresource), which fits the broad INTERACTION dimension better than USAGE or SPATIALITY alone.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Biodiversity is a property of the ecosystem.
cluster_relations.subject_class_group: Butterfly Ecology, Habitat, and Food Web
cluster_relations.object_class_group: Butterfly Ecology, Habitat, and Food Web

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a process or event takes place within or inside a specified spatial container or structure.
args.justification: This relation links the metamorphosis process to the chrysalis as the spatial container where the process takes place; a process-within-location predicate is appropriate.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a process or interaction takes place between or among specified entities or structures.
args.justification: This relation links the pollination process to flowers as the entities between which the interaction occurs, matching a process-between-participants semantics.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a quality, attribute, or property is characteristic of or belongs to a specified entity or system.
args.justification: Here biodiversity is modeled as a property or attribute of an ecosystem rather than as a process occurring inside it; a property-of predicate captures this semantics better than a pure spatial relation.

Both relations connect biological processes (metamorphosis, pollination) to spatial or structural contexts (a chrysalis as container, flowers as interaction partners), fitting a common class for spatial context of processes.
This relation assigns a property (biodiversity) to a system (ecosystem), which is best captured by a class for associating attributes or properties with entities.
Both relations primarily describe where or between which structures a process occurs, which is a spatial/contextual dimension.
The link expresses that biodiversity is an attribute or property of an ecosystem, fitting an attribute/quality assignment dimension rather than spatiality or causality.
